Graphical abstract In this study, the structure–activity relationships were investigated in converting biomass-derived furfural into cyclopentanone (CPO) or tetrahydrofuran alcohol (THFA) using a rinsing method to modulate the NiCoAl catalyst. Characterization of two catalysts, NiCoAl (without rinsing) and NiCoAl-R (with rinsing), reveals differences in morphology, composition, and acidity. Rinsing induced a transition from agglomerate to layered structure in NiCoAl-R, which exhibited higher acid strength and improved Lewis to Brønsted acid ratio. NiCoAl-R contained a high percentage of metal oxides, while NiCoAl had a high percentage of metallic species on its surface. These distinctions resulted in varied performance in FFA hydrogenolysis, with NiCoAl-R favoring CPO formation and NiCoAl facilitating THFA production. In situ DRIFTS experiments reveals differing furfural sorption states, and DFT calculations highlighted the higher activity of metal oxides in ring-opening reactions. This investigation elucidates the intricate relationship between catalyst properties and performance, offering insights for tailored catalyst design in biomass conversion. Keywords Furfural Structure–activity relationship Cyclopentanone Tetrahydrofuran alcohol NiCoAl Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The catalytic conversion of sustainable biomass or its derivatives into value-added chemicals or fuels is recognized as a pivotal approach for mitigating environmental impacts associated with fossil fuels and fostering sustainable development [1–4]. Furfural (FFA), derived from biomass, is an important chemical with versatile applications of producing a large number of chemicals (Scheme 1 ). FFA can undergo hydrogenation and deoxygenation reactions to yield furfuryl alcohol (FOL), tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFA), 2-methylfuran (2-MF), and 2-methyltetrahydrofuran (2-MTHF) [5–9]. Additionally, ring-opening and hydrogenation reactions of FFA lead to the formation of pentanediol [10] and cyclopentanone (CPO) [11,12]. Among the FFA-derived compounds, CPO and THFA are two important chemicals with applications in medicine, industry and agriculture [13,14]. Despite their crucial roles, their current industrial production relies on non-renewable fossil-based processes. For example, CPO is traditionally produced through the pyrolysis of adipic acid derivatives or the oxidation of cyclopentene [15]. In recent years, green routes through FFA hydrogenolysis over heterogenous catalysts have been developed. Various metal–acid bifunctional catalysts have been applied to synthesize THFA and CPO from FFA, summarized in Tables S1 and S2. Both noble-metal and non-precious metal catalysts, including Ru [16], Pd [17], Ni [18], and Cu [19–21], have been developed with good performance. These catalysts, with metal sites facilitating hydrogenation and acid sites managing oxygen removal, ring-opening, and rearrangement reactions, are crucial in this context. This study focuses on the bifunctional metal–acid NiCoAl trimetallic catalyst, exhibiting excellent performance in FFA hydrogenolysis to produce CPO and THFA. FFA hydrogenolysis over heterogenous catalysts is a structure-sensitive reaction, where the catalyst's surface properties play a pivotal role in determining reaction pathways and product selectivity [22]. Specifically, metallic species on the surface catalyze the hydrogenation of the furan ring and carbonyl group in a parallel sorption position, while acidic species catalyze ring-opening and rearrangement reactions in a tilted sorption position [23,24]. Controlling active sites on the surface is crucial for product selectivity in FFA hydrogenolysis. However, achieving exclusive production of a single product is challenging due to a lack of fundamental understanding regarding mechanisms dependent on active sites. Controls on active sites, including metal and acidic sites, are currently insufficient, impeding the development of efficient catalysts for FFA hydrogenolysis. The trimetallic catalyst NiCoAl, incorporating both metal and acidic sites, can ideally be tuned for exclusive production of CPO or THFA from FFA hydrogenolysis. This involves shifting reduced metals providing high hydrogenation activity to metal oxides providing active acidic sites. Although this approach has not been reported, it motivates the development of a novel method to control metal species on the surface, aiming to enhance the product selectivity of FFA hydrogenolysis. In this study, a simple approach involving a rinsing process during catalyst preparation was employed to control the composition of NiCoAl catalysts. Catalysts with or without rinsing process exhibited distinctive morphology, physical, acidic, and electronic properties, as revealed by various characterizations. The NiCoAl catalyst without rinsing exhibited a prevalence of metallic compositions on its surface, leading to high hydrogenation activity, low acidity, favorable parallel FFA sorption configuration, and therefore resulting in a high THFA yield of 95.6 %. Conversely, the rinsed NiCoAl catalyst demonstrated a dominance of metal oxides on its surface, resulting in increased acidity, the preferential titled FFA sorption configuration, and thus achieving a peak CPO yield of 94.4 %. Results from both in situ DRIFTS and density functional theory (DFT) calculations further proved the crucial role of metallic sites in hydrogenation and acidic sites in ring-opening reactions. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (99 %), Co(NO3)2·6H2O (99 %), NaOH (97 %), Furfural (99 %), cyclopentanone (99 %), Cyclopentanol (99 %), Furfuryl alcohol (98 %), and Tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (98 %) were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Bio-Chem Technology Co., Ltd. Guaiacol (98 %) and Al(CH3COO)3 (≥98 %) were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. All chemicals were used as received without further purification. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts A solution of NaOH (0.035 mol) in 50 ml deionized water (DI) was introduced to a beaker containing guaiacol (0.035 mol). The mixture was stirred at 500 rpm for 30 min, resulting in a dark brown mixture solution. Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, Co(NO3)2·6H2O, and Al(CH3COO)3were added to the solution, stirred at 400 rpm for 30 min, resulting in a precipitate. Then the precipitate was filtered, rinsed with DI water until the pH reached approximately 7, and dried to obtain the precursor. The catalyst precursor was calcined in a N2 flow (30 mL/min) at 600 ℃ for 1 h and reduced in a H2 flow (30 mL/min) at 450 ℃ for 4 h. The synthesized catalyst was denoted NiCoAl-R. The catalyst without rinsing was denoted NiCoAl. Bimetallic Ni-Co (NiCo or NiCo-R), Ni-Al (NiAl or NiAl-R), and Co-Al (CoAl or CoAl-R) catalysts were synthesized similarly. 2.3 Characterization methods Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) spectra (2θ = 5-90°; scanning speed: 0.05°/s) were recorded at 40 kV and 40 mA on a Rigaku SmartLab SE using copper Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). The valences of surface elements of the catalysts were analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS; Thermo Scientific K-Alpha) with an Al Kα (1486.6 eV) X-ray source. All XPS peaks were referenced to the C 1 s peak at 284.8 eV. The Ni, Co, and Al contents of the catalysts were quantitatively determined using inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-MS; Agilent 7800). The Ni, Co, and Al contents of the solution after reaction were quantitatively determined using inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-OES; Thermo Fisher iCAP 7400). Nitrogen sorption isotherms were recorded using a Micromeritics Instrument Corp's ASAP 2460 apparatus at 77 K. The specific surface area was calculated using the multipoint Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, and the average pore diameter (Dp, nm) and pore size distribution were calculated via the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. A field emission SEM (Zeiss Sigma 300) was used to characterize the specific morphologies. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) and energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDS) were performed on a FEI Tecnai F20 American FEI instrument. The average particle size was calculated statistically by selecting 100–150 particles from the TEM images. The NH3 temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) was performed using a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. In the TPD test, the catalyst was first pretreated in helium (30 mL/min) at 10 ℃/min to 150 ℃ for 1 h to remove any adsorbed water or volatile species. After cooling to 50 ℃, the catalyst was completely saturated with 30 mL/min 10 % NH3/He for 1 h. Then, the system was purged with 30 mL/min He for 1 h to remove physically adsorbed NH3 molecules. Finally, NH3-TPD analysis was performed by increasing the temperature of the sample to 800 ℃ at a heating rate of 10 ℃/min under a He flow (30 mL/min). The reduction properties of the catalysts were analyzed through the H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR; BELCAT-A). Prior to H2 adsorption, the catalyst was first pre-treated in Ar (30 mL/min) at a rate of 10 ℃/min to 150 ℃ for 1 h to remove any adsorbed water or volatile species. After the temperature stabilization, the gas was switched to an H2/Ar mixture (30 mL/min) and purged for 1 h. After the baseline stabilization, the temperature was ramped up to 800 ℃ at a rate of 10 ℃/min, and the signal was recorded by the detector. The Raman spectra of the samples are tested by a HORIBA HR Evolution Raman spectrometer with the excitation wavelength of 532 nm. Basic strengths of the catalysts (H_) were determined by using Hammett indicators. About 10 mg of the catalyst sample was shaken with 2 mL of a solution of Hammett indicators diluted with methanol and left to equilibrate for 12 h. The system must be isolated from outside air (H2O, CO2) during measurement. After the equilibration, the color on the catalyst was noted. The following Hammett indicators were used: neutral red (H_= 6.8), bromthymol blue (H_= 7.2), phenolphthalein (H_= 9.3), 2,4-dinitroaniline (H_= 15.0), and 4-nitroaniline (H_= 18.4). The acid properties were evaluated by infrared spectroscopy with adsorbed pyridine using a Tensor 27 spectrometer (Py-FTIR). The catalyst was first purified by vacuum (200 ℃, 1 × 10-4 Pa) for 1 h, then cooled to room temperature to scan the spectrum as a background. After adsorption of pyridine at room temperature, the program was warmed up to 150 ℃ for vacuum desorption (1 × 10-4 Pa) for half an hour, then cooled down to room temperature and the IR spectra were recorded in the region of 1400–1700 cm−1. To probe the interaction and reaction between catalyst and furfural, in situ DRIFTS was performed using a PerkinElmer Spectrum 3 equipped with a MCT detector (cooled with liquid N2) and a chamber with ZnSe window. The sample underwent a 30-minute purge with N2 to eliminate surface impurities and record the background spectrum. A N2 gas flow of 50 mL/min served as the carrier gas, and FFA was introduced into the chamber at 160 °C, with subsequent collection of the IR signals. Details on DFT calculations are illustrated in the supporting information. 2.4 Catalyst performance evaluation Reactions were conducted in a 30 mL high-pressure autoclave. Typically, 1 mmol FFA, 30 mg catalyst, and 15 mL H2O were introduced into the reactor. The reactor was purged with H2 five times to remove air in the reactor, pressurized with H2 to the desired pressure, sealed and then heated to the desired temperature. Once the reactions were completed, the reactor was cooled to room temperature. The products were quantitatively determined using a Shimadzu GC-FID 2014C instrument equipped with an HP-INNOWAX capillary column (30 m × 0.25 μm × 0.25 mm) and a flame ionization detector (FID). The compositions of the products were further confirmed using GCMS-QP 2010. The heating procedure of was following: the oven temperature was heated to 60 ℃ and kept for 2 min, then increased to 240 ℃ at 10 ℃/min, and held for 10 min. The GC inlet temperature was 260 ℃, the MS interface temperature was 260 ℃, and the ion source temperature was 250 ℃. Same heating procedure was used for the Shimadzu GC-FID 2014C. The FFA conversion, product yield, and turnover frequency (TOF) were calculated with the equation shown below: (1) F F A c o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = M o l e s o f F F A c o n v e r t e d M o l e s o f F F A l o a d e d × 100 % (2) P r o d u c t s y i e l d ( % ) = M o l e s o f p r o d u c t s M o l e s o f F F A l o a d e d × 100 % (3) T O F = F F A c o n v e r t e d ( m o l ) R e a c t i o n t i m e ( h ) × A c t i v e m e t a l s ( m o l ) × 100 % For TOF calculations, the active metals were assumed to be Ni and Co and reaction time was 1 min. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of catalysts 3.1.1 Modification of physical properties of catalysts by rinsing To probe the effect of rinse on the physical properties of catalysts, various characterization techniques including ICP-MS, N2-sorption, powder XRD, SEM, TEM-EDS mapping, and Raman were employed with results listed in Table S3 and Fig. 1 . The ICP-MS tests show mole ratios of Ni/Co/Al ∼ 41/40/19 in both NiCoAl and NiCoAl-R catalysts. Fig. 1a illustrates the powder XRD patterns of catalysts, revealing notable alterations in catalyst compositions induced by the rinsing process. The NiCoAl-R catalyst displays broad peaks at 2θ = 36.5° and 42.4°, corresponding to the (1 1 1) and (2 0 0) planes of CoO (PDF#48–1719), respectively. The peak at 2θ = 36.8° is attributed to the (3 1 1) plane of Co3O4 (PDF#74–1657). Peaks at 2θ = 37.2°, 43.3°, and 62.9° are attributed to the (1 0 1), (0 1 2), and (1 1 0) planes of NiO (PDF#44–1159), respectively. These peaks in the NiCoAl-R catalyst are broad and weak, indicating a high dispersion of various metals, with no peaks for Ni0 and Co0 observed. Conversely, the NiCoAl catalyst exhibits peaks at 2θ = 44.5°, 51.8°, and 76.4°, attributed to the (1 1 1), (2 0 0), and (2 2 0) planes of Ni0, respectively (PDF#04–0850). Two peaks at 2θ = 31.7° and 45.4° are related to the (2 2 0) and (4 0 0) planes of CoAl2O4 (PDF#44–0160). Clearly, rinsing significantly influences the catalyst compositions. This is further evident when comparing other bimetallic catalysts with or without rinsing. For example, the CoAl catalyst displays Co0, CoAl2O4, or Co3O4 peaks in the XRD pattern, while only CoO peaks are observed in the CoAl-R catalyst. Similarly, the NiCo catalyst shows intensified peaks of the Ni0/Co0 composition, while the XRD peaks of metal oxides are more pronounced than the reduced Ni0/Co0 composition in the NiCo-R catalyst. To conclude, the rinsing step during preparation induces modifications in the compositions of catalysts. Specifically, catalysts without rinse led to the reduction of metal species, while the rinsed catalysts maintain oxide states. These variations in catalyst compositions result in diverse activities in the hydrogenolysis of FFA, leading to distinct product selectivity, as evidenced by the catalytic performance tests. SEM and TEM snapshots were used to examine the effect of rinse on the morphology of the catalysts. The NiCoAl catalyst exhibits an agglomerate structure (Fig. 1b), while the NiCoAl-R catalyst shows a layered structure (Fig. 1c) which leads to a larger specific surface area. This alteration suggests that rinsing can modify the catalyst's morphology, diversify the interaction between the catalyst and FFA molecules, therefore leading to distinct performance in FFA hydrogenolysis. The NiCoAl catalyst comprises nanoparticles ranging from 4-11 nm, with an average particle size of 6.94 nm (Fig. 1e). HR-TEM snapshots reveal the presents of Ni0, Co0, and CoO planes (Fig. 1f). On the other hand, the NiCoAl-R catalyst contains NPs ranging from 4-10 nm, with an average particle size of 6.62 nm (Fig. 1n). HR-TEM snapshots indicate the presence of NiO, CoO, and Co3O4 planes, with Ni0 and Co0 absent (Fig. 1o), aligning with the XRD observations. The HAADF-STEM images and corresponding EDS mappings reveal uniform distribution of C, O, Ni, Co, and Al elements in both catalysts (Fig. 1h-m and q-v). Further insight into the structure and properties of the samples was gained through Raman spectroscopy. The D and G bands at 1340 cm−1 and 1590 cm−1 [25], respectively, indicate a strong interaction between carbon and metal during preparation. Both NiCoAl and NiCoAl-R catalysts show similar D and G bands, indicating negligible effect of carbon on their catalytic activity. The observed Raman bands at 190 cm−1, 476 cm−1, 519 cm−1, 670 cm−1 for the NiCoAl sample are assigned to CoAl2O4 [26], consistent with the XRD results. The rinsing process also affects particle sizes and specific surface area of trimetallic catalysts. The average particle size of NPs was 6.94 nm for the NiCoAl catalyst and 6.62 nm for the NiCoAl-R catalyst. The average particle size of NPs decreased slightly after rinse, probably due to the fact that rinse promotes the formation of metal oxides, leading to a more homogeneous dispersion of particles and preventing the agglomeration of NPs. The specific surface area of the NiCoAl catalyst was 118.01 m2/g, with a pore volume of 0.25 cm3/g (Table S3). After rinsing, the specific surface area of the NiCoAl-R catalyst increased to 195.54 m2/g, and the pore volume increased to 0.39 cm3/g, although the average pore size did not change significantly. The reduced specific surface area and volume of the NiCoAl catalyst were probably due to the blockage caused by residual salts. It was demonstrated that rinsing increased the specific surface area and pore volume in the NiCoAl-R catalyst, attributed to the layered structure observed in SEM analysis compared to the agglomerate structure of the NiCoAl catalyst (Fig. 1b and c). 3.1.2 Modification of acidic properties by rinsing Acidic properties play an important role in FFA hydrogenolysis, as active acid sites significantly affect the reaction pathways, product selectivity and overall catalytic performance [27]. The acidic properties of the NiCo, NiCo-R, NiCoAl and NiCoAl-R catalysts were initially examined by NH3-TPD (Fig. 2 a and Table S4). The NiCo catalyst displays a NH3-desorption peak at 527.9 ℃, representing a strong acid center with an acid amount of 5.77 mmol/g. The NiCoAl desorption peaks are at 83.6 ℃ and 391.5 ℃, with the latter indicating a medium-strong acid center with an acid amount of 4.077 mmol/g. It is noteworthy that this desorption peak ranging from 300 ℃ to about 700 ℃ demonstrates that the addition of the Al species has expanded range of catalyst's acid. The NiCo-R catalyst displays a desorption peak at 447.2 ℃, indicating a strong acid center with an acid amount of 4.373 mmol/g. In the NiCoAl-R catalyst, desorption peaks were at 87.1 ℃ and 554.7 ℃, with the latter being a strong acid center with an amount of 6.38 mmol/g. The inclusion of Al species increased the strong acid strength of the NiCoAl-R catalyst by 1.5-fold compared to the NiCo-R catalyst. Similarly, rinsing enhanced the acid strength of NiCoAl-R over NiCoAl catalysts by a factor of 1.56. Thus, rinse modulates the acid strength of NiCoAl catalysts, affecting FFA hydrogenolysis. Acid type and strength were characterized by Py-FTIR spectroscopy (Fig. 2b and Table S5). Peaks at 1448 and 1608 cm−1 are attributed to chemisorbed pyridine on Lewis acidic sites, while the peak at 1490 cm−1 denotes a hybrid Lewis and Brønsted acidic site. Although both Lewis acid and Brønsted acid promote the FFA hydrogenolysis, Lewis acid plays key role in the ring rearrangement and hydrolysis steps, with high Lewis acidity favoring the ring opening and ring rearrangement of FFA into CPO [12,28]. Among the tested catalysts, the NiCoAl catalyst had a Lewis acidity of 37.2 μmol/g. The Lewis acidity of the catalyst increased significantly after rinse, with the NiCoAl-R catalyst displaying a Lewis acidity of 57.8 μmol/g and the highest Lewis to Brønsted acid ratio (L/B ratio) of 18.6. This represented a 1.55-fold increase compared to the NiCoAl catalyst. The analysis of physical properties suggested that the rinsing process led to a higher composition of metal oxides, a significant source of Lewis acid. In contrast, the formation of reduced metals in catalysts without rinsing shows the lower amount of Lewis acid. Collectively, the catalysts exhibited distinct acid behaviors, influencing FFA hydrogenolysis. Additionally, the basic strength of the catalysts was assessed using the Hammett indicator method, and Fig. 2c provides a concise overview of the acid-base strengths of the prepared catalysts. The experimental findings revealed that all the unrinsed catalysts exhibited the highest basic strengths, ranging from 7.2 to 9.3. In contrast, the catalysts subjected to the rinsing process showed a notable decrease in basic strength. Specifically, the NiCoAl-R catalyst displayed the lowest basic strength, falling below 6.8, and other rinsed catalysts exhibited basic strengths within the range of 6.8–7.2. A previous study has proposed that Lewis base sites facilitate catalytic hydrogenation in collaboration with metal sites [29]. Therefore, the observations in this study suggest that the robust basic strength in the unrinsed catalysts promotes the conversion of FFA to THFA. Conversely, the acid sites in the rinsed catalysts favor the production of CPO through FFA hydrogenolysis. This correlation aligns with the catalytic performance results observed in this study. The effect of sodium ions was further investigated. Results indicated that external sodium did not significantly alter the basic strength of the rinsed catalysts (Table S6), suggesting a minimal impact of sodium ions on the acid-base properties of the catalysts. 3.1.3 Modification of electronic properties by rinsing Surface metal species directly interact with reactants, affecting the electron transfer and therefore determining the activity of catalysts. The valences of surface metal species were examined by XPS (Fig. 3 a and b, Tables S7 and S8). In the Ni 2p XPS profiles of the catalysts, peaks at 852.7 and 870.2 eV correspond to metallic Ni0 2p3/2 and 2p1/2, respectively [30]. Peaks at 854.7 and 871.9 eV are assigned to Ni2+ (NiO), whereas the peaks at 856.0 and 873.6 eV are attributed to Ni2+ ions surrounded by Al3+ or Co2+ ions with O2– interconnections [31]. Peaks at 861.5 and 879.2 eV are associated with satellite peaks of Ni 2p3/2 and 2p1/2, respectively. In the Co 2p XPS profiles, peaks at 779.8 and 795.1 eV are assigned to Co3+ (Co3O4) 2p3/2 and 2p1/2, respectively, the peaks at 781.2 and 796.5 eV are assigned to Co2+ (CoO) 2p3/2 and 2p1/2, respectively, and the peaks at 782.8 and 797.5 eV are assigned to Co2+ (Co3O4) 2p3/2 and 2p1/2, respectively, or Co2+ surrounded by Al3+ or Ni2+ with O2– interconnections [32]. Peaks at 778.4 and 793.7 eV corresponds to the Co0 composition. The NiCoAl-R and NiCo-R catalysts exclusively demonstrate Ni2+ on the surface, while the NiCoAl and NiCo catalysts show both Ni0 and Ni2+ on the surface. Notably, the NiCoAl catalyst demonstrates the highest percentage of Ni0 on the surface among the tested catalysts. On the other hand, the NiCoAl catalyst without rinsing displays the Co0 on the surface, making it the only tested catalyst showing Co0 composition. These observations align with the XRD results. It also suggests the rinsing process hinders the reduction of metal oxides, while the absence of rinsing facilitates the reduction of metal oxides due to the inherent basicity in the trimetallic catalysts [33]. The reducibility of the catalysts was examined by H2-TPR analysis (Fig. 3c). Both catalysts exhibited a multi-step reduction process at temperatures ranging from 193 to 753 ℃. The NiCoAl catalyst exhibited weak and broad peaks at the lower temperatures of 256 and 320 ℃ attributed to the reduction of isolated NiO to Ni0, broad peaks at the middle temperatures of 421 and 548 ℃ assigned to the reduction of CoOx to Co0, and a peak at 681 ℃ attributed to the reduction of Co2+ in the defective Co1-xAl2O4-x structure [34]. Conversely, the NiCoAl-R catalyst exhibited peaks related to the reduction of CoOx to Co0 and NiO to Ni0 peaks at higher temperatures compared to the NiCoAl catalyst. This observation is consistent with the observed surface compositions in the physical characterizations, where the NiCoAl catalyst demonstrated the presence of Ni0 and Co0, while the NiCoAl-R catalyst exclusively featured metal oxide compositions. 3.2 Catalytic performance and stability of catalysts The catalysts exhibit varied physical, acidic, and electronic properties, leading to distinct catalytic activity in FFA hydrogenolysis. The reactions were performed under the conditions of 160 ℃, 3.0 MPa H2, and 8 h, with the results listed in Table 1 . Negligible loss of carbon was observed with well-maintained carbon balance. When the NiCo catalyst was used, FFA was completely converted to give yields of 48.5 % THFA and 51.4 % FOL, while no CPO and CPL were observed. This is owing to low acidity and the presence of Ni0 on the surface. Similarly, a higher yield of FOL (82.9 %) was obtained using the NiAl catalyst compared to the NiCo catalyst, while a lower yield of THFA was obtained due to no Ni0 was observed on the surface. The CoAl catalyst, exhibiting a 76.8 % yield of CPO, proved effective in promoting the conversion of FFA to CPO. Notably, the NiCoAl catalyst produced high yield of THFA (95.6 %), probably due to its highest exposed Ni0 and Co0 facilitating the hydrogenation reaction, and low acidity preventing the ring-opening reactions and rearrangements. The THFA yield from FFA over the NiCoAl catalyst was comparable to results reported in previous studies (Table S1). On the other hand, when the catalysts were rinsed, the CPO yields increased to 21.5 % and 43.0 % for the NiCo-R and NiAl-R catalysts, respectively. The CoAl-R catalyst showed a CPO yield similar to the CoAl catalyst, emphasizing the crucial role of CoAl species in promoting FFA to CPO. The introduction of Ni species to the catalyst altered the reaction pathway in FFA hydrogenolysis due to its high hydrogenation activity. Nevertheless, the NiCoAl-R catalyst showed a high yield of CPO (94.4 %) owing to its highest acidity and the absence of Ni0 and Co0 species on the catalyst’s surface. This CPO yield was comparable to results in previous studies (Table S2). Moreover, the TOFs for both NiCoAl and NiCoAl-R were higher than other catalysts used in this study, demonstrating possible synergistic effects between components of catalysts. The shared intermediate, FOL, was further converted into distinct products over NiCoAl and NiCoAl-R catalysts within a short reaction time of 30 min. FOL was selectively converted to THFA over NiCoAl, while it was converted to CPO over NiCoAl-R. This observation highlights the distinct catalytic properties of NiCoAl compared to its rinsed counterpart, NiCoAl-R. Fig. 4a and b illustrate the product evolution for FFA hydrogenolysis at varying reaction times. The NiCoAl catalyst demonstrated high hydrogenation activity, initially converting FFA to FOL at a fast rate, which was subsequently converted to THFA. In contrast, the NiCoAl-R initially formed FOL at a slower rate, which was then further converted to CPO. This difference in behavior is attributed to the Ni0 and Co0 species present in the NiCoAl catalyst while a high concentration of Lewis acidity in the NiCoAl-R catalyst. Fig. 4 c shows a reaction order of 0.3 for H2 over the NiCoAl-R catalyst, while the NiCoAl catalyst exhibited a reaction of 0.5. This suggests a fast hydrogenation reaction for both catalysts. The higher reaction order for H2 over the NiCoAl catalysts is due to consecutive hydrogenation reactions following the formation FOL. The acidity tests have unveiled distinctive properties between rinsed and unrinsed catalysts, with unrinsed variants exhibiting elevated base strength. Notably, this base strength might be attributed to the incorporation of NaOH during the preparation process. Post-reaction, the pH of the catalytic systems was scrutinized, revealing a pH of around 7 for the NiCoAl-R catalyst and approximately 7.5 for the NiCoAl catalyst. This discrepancy may be resulted from a potential leaching of base during the reaction. To delve into the impact of external base, NaOH was introduced to adjust the pH of the NiCoAl-R catalyst reaction system, targeting pH values of approximately 7.5 and 8 (Fig. 4d). Results showed that, under external alkaline conditions, while the conversion rate of FFA and the selectivity of CPO experienced marginal decreases, the primary product remained CPO. This observation suggests the basicity of NiCoAl-R originated from inherent properties, highlighting the pivotal role of the rinsing process in modulating the inherent acidity and alkalinity of the catalyst. The recuse potential of the NiCoAl-R and NiCoAl catalysts was investigated (Fig. 5 ). The catalyst after the reaction was collected and directly used in the next FFA hydrogenation reaction under the same conditions without additional treatment. Notably, the NiCoAl-R catalyst exhibited remarkable resilience, with only marginal decreases in FFA conversion and CPO yield observed at the fifth test compared to the fresh catalyst (Conversion: 100 % vs. 95.3 %; CPO yield: 94.3 % vs. 82.9 %), as depicted in Fig. 5a. This robust performance was further validated by XRD and XPS analyses, which revealed no substantial differences between the fresh and spent NiCoAl-R catalysts (Fig. 5b, 5c, and S1a). Conversely, the NiCoAl catalyst displayed a shift in the main product from THFA to CPO during the recycling tests (Fig. 5d). Various characterizations were performed to probe the properties of the spent catalyst. The XRD patterns of the spent NiCoAl catalyst exhibited diminished peaks corresponding to metallic Ni or Co, coupled with increased intensity in peaks attributed to metal oxides. These observations suggest a potential decline in hydrogenation activity and an increase in acidity. (Fig. S1b). Indeed, in the XPS spectra of the NiCoAl catalysts after recycling (Fig. 5e and f), the NiO content in the Ni 2p spectra notably increased compared to the fresh catalysts. This increase is attributed to the oxidation of the high hydrogenation site of Ni0, resulting in the formation of Ni2+ on the catalyst surface. Meanwhile, the intensity of the deconvoluted peak corresponding to Co0 decreased for the spent NiCoAl catalyst in comparison to the fresh catalyst. Furthermore, Py-FTIR was employed to examine the changes in the acidity of the catalysts (Fig. S2, Tables S9 and S10). Interestingly, the Lewis acidic sites of the two catalysts exhibited distinct alterations after the recycling tests. The amount of Lewis acid in the spent NiCoAl-R catalyst slightly decreased from 57.8 μmol/g to 50.8 μmol/g. In contrast, the NiCoAl catalyst showed a notable increase in its Lewis acid content from 37.2 μmol/g to 45.0 μmol/g. This observation underscores the significance of Lewis acidic sites in the conversion of FFA to CPO, with the abundance of Lewis acidic sites facilitating the ring-opening and rearrangement reactions for FFA hydrogenolysis to CPO. Additionally, the solution elements after recycling were examined using ICP to detect possible metal leaching, and no leaching of metals was observed for both the NiCoAl-R and NiCoAl catalysts. 3.3 Structure-Activity relationship The characterizations of the catalysts and catalytic performance tests have shown that the reaction pathways of FFA hydrogenolysis depend on the catalyst structure. To delve deeper into the impact of catalyst structure on the catalyst reaction pathway, the interaction and reaction between FFA and the NiCoAl or NiCoAl-R catalysts was explored by in situ DRIFTS experiments, respectively. The in situ DRIFTS spectra for the NiCoAl catalyst and FFA is shown in Fig. 6 a. The broad bands at 1330, 1712, and 1750 cm−1 are attributed to the stretching vibration of the v(C = O) band, and the broad and strong band at 1596 cm−1 is attributed to the interaction between the furan ring and the catalyst. These observations indicate a strong chemisorption of FFA on the NiCoAl catalyst with a parallel adsorption model. Therefore, the high hydrogenation capacity of NiCoAl during the FFA hydrogenolysis leads to the complete hydrogenation of parallel-adsorbed FFA, generating THFA. This finding aligns with previous studies indicating that the parallel-adsorbed position of FFA can facilitate the full hydrogenation of the furan ring and the carbonyl moiety to THFA [22,35]. Previous study has suggested that the formation of CPO from the Piancatelli rearrangement of FFA an FOL without hydrogenation of furan ring [36]. Therefore, the contact between NiCoAl-R and furan ring was assumed negligible to prevent the hydrogenation of furan ring. Here, the in situ DRIFTS spectra for the NiCoAl-R catalyst and FFA is shown in Fig. 6b. The bands at 1710 and 1721 cm−1 are attributed to the stretching vibration of the v(C = O) band, with the intensity of this bond significantly increasing over time. Although the band at 1575 cm−1 attributed to the interaction with furan ring and the band at 1475 cm−1 attributed to the stretching vibration of v(C = C) band were observed, the intensities of these bands are negligible suggesting weak interaction between the furan ring and the NiCoAl-R catalyst. Therefore, the strong carbonyl adsorption of FFA with weaker furan ring adsorption resulted in its tilted adsorption of FFA on the NiCoAl-R catalyst. The titled adsorption of FFA, relatively weak hydrogenation capacity, and abundant acid sites of the NiCoAl-R catalyst compared to NiCoAl together lead to the hydrogenation of carbonyl group and subsequent ring opening of the furan ring. These results illustrate that the rinsing process alters the structure of catalyst, and therefore changes the adsorption configuration of FFA on catalysts, further affecting the reaction pathways of FFA (Fig. 6f). The reaction kinetics of FFA hydrogenolysis were further investigated at different temperatures (155, 160, 165 and 170 °C). The apparent activation energy (Ea) was 24.02 kJ/mol for the NiCoAl catalyst, while it increased to 49.38 kJ/mol for the NiCoAl-R catalyst (Fig. 6c and S3). A similar trend was observed in the hydrogenolysis of FOL, where the NiCoAl-R catalyst exhibited a higher Ea of 68.7 kJ/mol, compared to a lower Ea of 29.1 kJ/mol for the NiCoAl catalyst (Fig. 6d and S3). The main product was FOL for both catalysts. It indicates that the NiCoAl-R catalyst shows higher activity of hydrogenation of carbonyl group of FFA, probably due to its high occupancies of metallic states of Ni0 and Co0 on the surface compared to the NiCoAl catalyst. It also suggests that the hydrogenation of FFA to FOL requires low energy and can be readily achieved, whereas the conversion of FFA to CPO requires steps such as ring opening and ring rearrangement, necessitating higher energy to facilitate the reaction. To further explore this, DFT calculations of FOL to the ring-opening states were performed using two slabs, Ni(1 1 1) and Co3O4(3 1 1), both recognized as active surfaces for hydrogenation and ring-opening reactions of furfural [22,33]. The energy plot is shown in the Fig. 6e, and the optimized configurations are shown in the Figs. S4 and S5. The Ni(1 1 1) showed a higher affinity between FOL and the slab compared to the Co3O4(3 1 1) slab, due to the strong interactions between the furan ring and the Ni(1 1 1) slab, consistent with the in situ DRIFTS results. However, the Ni(1 1 1) presented higher activation energies in the removal of the OH group from the FOL reactant and the subsequent ring-opening step than the Co3O4(3 1 1) slab. This suggests that the metal oxide Co3O4 presents a higher activity in facilitating the ring-opening reaction of the furan ring, aligning with the assumption that the metal oxides in the NiCoAl-R catalyst play an important role in promoting FFA hydrogenolysis to CPO through ring-opening reactions. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, this study systematically explores the impact of a simple process, rinsing operation, on the properties and catalytic performance in the FFA hydrogenolysis. The characterizations of NiCoAl and NiCoAl-R catalysts unveiled distinct compositions, physical attributes, acidity, and electronic properties. The NiCoAl catalyst has large amounts of metallic compositions on the surface, resulting in high hydrogenation activity, low acidity, and high selectivity to THFA. In contrast, the NiCoAl-R catalyst contains dominant metal oxides on its surface, leading to increased acidity and high selectivity toward CPO. In situ DRIFTS tests revealed variations in the sorption state of FFA, with parallel adsorption on NiCoAl and tilted adsorption on NiCoAl-R. Furthermore, the DFT calculations suggest the high activity of Co3O4 to facilitate the OH removal and subsequent ring-opening reaction of the intermediate FOL. This study provides valuable insights into the relationship between the structure of NiCoAl catalyst and activity in FFA hydrogenolysis, demonstrating effective product control through a straightforward rinsing process of the NiCoAl catalyst. coredata.dc:description: In this study, the structure–activity relationships were investigated in converting biomass-derived furfural into cyclopentanone (CPO) or tetrahydrofuran alcohol (THFA) using a rinsing method to modulate the NiCoAl catalyst. Characterization of two catalysts, NiCoAl (without rinsing) and NiCoAl-R (with rinsing), reveals differences in morphology, composition, and acidity. Rinsing induced a transition from agglomerate to layered structure in NiCoAl-R, which exhibited higher acid strength and improved Lewis to Brønsted acid ratio. NiCoAl-R contained a high percentage of metal oxides, while NiCoAl had a high percentage of metallic species on its surface. These distinctions resulted in varied performance in FFA hydrogenolysis, with NiCoAl-R favoring CPO formation and NiCoAl facilitating THFA production. In situ DRIFTS experiments reveals differing furfural sorption states, and DFT calculations highlighted the higher activity of metal oxides in ring-opening reactions. This investigation elucidates the intricate relationship between catalyst properties and performance, offering insights for tailored catalyst design in biomass conversion.
